column13: Solution Description

column7: Under its listed holding Company, JB Hi-Fi Limited, the JB Hi-Fi Group brings together two of Australia's best-known and most trusted retail brands, JB Hi-Fi and The Good Guys. The Group sells an extensive range of consumer electronics, white goods appliances and home entertainment at great prices combined with genuine personal service from our specialist staff.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: The scope of JB HI-FI sustainability reporting and data metrics includes critical performance data from the JB HI-FI and The Good Guys.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: This is the JB Hi-Fi Group's fourth Sustainability Report and serves as a review of our sustainability performance covering the reporting period 1 July 2022 Ã¢ÂÂ 30 June 2023.

In FY23, JB HI-FI took the opportunity to re-assess the material topics covered in our Sustainability Plan. It sought feedback from its team members and external stakeholders (such as suppliers, non-government organisations (NGOs), industry bodies, regulators, and investors) on what they believe to be the critical environmental, social and governance (ESG) topics of focus for the Group.

column13: Business Assurance Team refers to a group within an organization responsible for ensuring that business processes, operations, and activities comply with internal policies, industry regulations, and legal requirements. They are often tasked with evaluating risks, implementing controls, and monitoring performance to safeguard the business operations' integrity, security, and effectiveness.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: The Group comprises two leading retail brands: JB Hi-Fi, with a focus on Technology and Consumer Electronics, and The Good Guys, with a focus on Home Appliances and Consumer Electronics. The value proposition for each brand centres around the best brands at low prices, supported by exceptional customer service across our 322-store network.
In FY23, JB HI-FI and our controlled subsidiary companies employed 14500 team members across Australia and New Zealand.
In FY23, JB HI-FI Companies service providers and outsourced subcontractors engaged for installation and set-up services for some of our products.
The Board comprises eight directors, six non-executive directors, the Chairman, and two executive directors, the Group Chief Executive Officer and the Group Chief Financial Officer.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: A copy of the Company's Board Composition & Succession Policy, which includes selecting and appointing directors, can be found on the Company's investor website at https://investors.jbhifi.com.au/. The Board will undertake appropriate checks before appointing any person or putting forward to shareholders a candidate for election as a director, including checks to ensure that the candidate has sufficient capacity to perform the role.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mr. Stephen Goddard is the Chairman of JB HI-FI Group.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: Overseeing the business and affairs of the Group refers to the responsibility of a governing body, such as a board of directors or executive management team, to manage and direct the overall operations, strategies, and decision-making processes of a company or organization and its subsidiaries or affiliated entities. It includes setting objectives, approving major initiatives, allocating resources, monitoring performance, and ensuring compliance with legal and regulatory requirements.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: Demonstrating leadership of the Group entails exhibiting qualities and behaviours that inspire, guide, and motivate individuals within the organization toward shared goals and objectives. Group leaders are responsible for setting a clear vision, fostering a positive organizational culture, making strategic decisions, and aligning the efforts of team members to achieve desired outcomes.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: Monitoring the performance of management involves assessing the effectiveness, efficiency, and adherence to goals and objectives of the individuals or teams responsible for leading and directing the organization's operations. This process typically includes evaluating key performance indicators (KPIs), financial metrics, strategic initiatives, and other relevant factors to gauge how healthy management executes its responsibilities and delivers results.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: An Audit and Risk Management Committee is a specialized group within an organization's governance structure, typically consisting of members of the Board of Directors or other high-level executives. This Committee is responsible for overseeing and providing guidance on matters related to financial reporting, internal controls, risk management, and compliance.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The remuneration and nomination committee, sometimes called a Compensation and nomination committee or a Compensation and Governance Committee, is a specialized group within an organization's governance structure, typically composed of members of the board of directors or other high-level executives. This Committee oversees matters related to executive compensation, board member nominations, and corporate governance practices.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: The remuneration framework typically encompasses various components, including base salaries, bonuses, stock options, equity awards, incentives, benefits, and other forms of compensation. Approving the Group's remuneration framework refers to the responsibility of the governing body, such as the board of directors or a specialized committee, to review, evaluate, and ultimately endorse the structure, policies, and practices governing the compensation and benefits awarded to employees across the entire organization and its subsidiaries or divisions.

column7: Directors must promptly disclose to the Board interests in contracts, other directorships or offices held, possible related party transactions and any other personal interests relating to the Company's affairs. Directors must quickly inform the BoardBoard about any involvement in contracts, additional directorial roles, potential related-party dealings, or significant personal interests about the Company's matters.

column13: The Group has adopted a Code of Conduct to guide directors, executives, and employees on what the Group deems to be acceptable behaviour. The Group will ensure that the Board and Audit and Risk Management Committee are informed of any material incidents that breach this Code.

The BoardBoard has approved a Continuous Disclosure Policy to ensure that the procedures for identifying and disclosing material price-sensitive information by the Corporations Act and ASX Listing Rules are articulated. This policy sets out the obligations of employees in respect of such information.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: JB HI-FI is delighted to welcome Christy to the Board. Christy brings great strategic expertise and significant experience in working with retail companies. Her skills complement our existing directors, and we look forward to working together.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The Review of Board Performance involves assessing the board of directors' effectiveness, performance, and contributions in fulfilling its duties and responsibilities to govern the organization effectively. This process is essential for enhancing board governance, accountability, decision-making, and identifying improvement areas.

The Company's remuneration strategy seeks to appropriately reward, incentivize and retain critical employees. The BoardBoard aims to achieve this by setting competitive remuneration packages ("packages") that include a mix of fixed remuneration and incentives under the Company's Variable Reward Plan ("VRP").

The Remuneration and Nominations Committee annually reviews the remuneration packages of Executive KMP and makes recommendations to the BoardBoard. Remuneration packages are reviewed with due regard to performance and data on remuneration paid by comparable companies.
Fixed remuneration is paid through base salary, motor vehicle allowances and superannuation. No elements of fixed remuneration are dependent on performance conditions.

The Group operates a variable reward plan to incentivize, attract and retain valued executives. The VRP allows flexibility in setting performance targets yearly to consider changing trading conditions, which is particularly important in a fast-moving and volatile retail environment.

Under the VRP, performance is assessed at the end of each financial year against a scorecard of robust measures. 75% of the rewards under the plan for each executive depend on financial targets, and the remaining 25% of the scorecard is based on strategic measures approved by the board and aligned with the Group's long-term corporate plans.

column7: In FY23, the Total Compensation of Key Management Personnel is $12,564,038.

column13: A Group Sustainability Plan is a comprehensive strategy developed by JB HI-FI to integrate sustainability principles into its operations, practices, and decision-making processes across all business units and functions. This plan outlines the organization's commitments, goals, initiatives, and targets related to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors to drive long-term value creation, resilience, and positive impact for all stakeholders.

The ASX Corporate Governance Council Principles refer to a set of principles and recommendations developed by the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) Corporate Governance Council. These principles provide guidelines for listed companies in Australia to promote good corporate governance practices and enhance transparency, accountability, and integrity in their operations.

The Group's Policy refers to a set of guidelines, rules, and principles established by a company or organization to govern specific aspects of its operations, conduct, or decision-making processes. These policies ensure consistency, compliance with laws and regulations, and alignment with the organization's values, objectives, and strategic priorities.

Corporate governance refers to the rules, practices, processes, and structures by which a company is directed and controlled. The primary objectives of corporate governance are to promote transparency, accountability, fairness, and integrity in the organization's operations and decision-making processes while safeguarding the interests of shareholders and other stakeholders.

column7: During the 2023 financial year, the Company has complied with the spirit of the principles contained in the ASX Recommendations.

column13: The Group has a practical risk management framework in line with ISO31000, which enables management to identify and manage risk appropriately. The Committee regularly reviews and revises this framework. The BoardBoard reviews the framework at least annually to satisfy itself that it continues to be sound and that the Group is operating with due regard to the risk appetite set by the BoardBoard.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: The Director's Report is a critical component of a company's annual Report, providing an overview of the Company's performance, activities, and financial results for the reporting period. The Director's Report aims to provide transparency, insight, and accountability regarding the Company's operations and strategic direction.
